text: Kaleb finds a coin near a railroad track. It looks flat and a little bent, so he guesses it has been run over by a train. He decides to use this unusual coin to determine how many hours of screen time he will have for the next 30 days. By the end of the 30 days, there were only seven days with 1 hour of screen time. His mother is suspicious of the coin.

Why is Kaleb’s mother suspicious of the coin?

What does it mean for a coin to be “fair”?

She says, “You call a coin a fair coin if heads and tails are equally likely results of a coin toss. That is, if you flip the coin many times, in the long run a head should turn up about as many times as a tail. This means that you have the same chance of getting heads as getting tails.” Kaleb and his mother wonder if Kaleb’s coin is a fair coin.

Suppose you toss a number cube. The possible outcomes are the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6. Each number is equally likely to occur.

What are other outcomes we can consider when tossing a number cube?

Are they equally likely?
